div.head: CHRISTMASTIDE
div.p: "Christmas comes but once a year,

And when it comes it brings good cheer." So runs the old coupletand as far as the first line is concerned it is almost universally correct. But it fails to take into account such an exceptional state of things as that to be found in this country. Here we have a large Greek element, and while the Anglican Protestant Church and the Latin Churches generally celebrate the birth of Christ on December 25th, the Greek and Eastern Churches defer their celebration till the 7th of January-the period of the Epipbany. Consequently we get in Egypt two Christmas Days in the year each observed by a large number of commercial men ; indeed, so large is the Greek community here that practically business is suspended in most houses on the later as well as the earlier date. What a boon would this be considered in the busy City of London--at least by the employés, for such a state of things would hardly commend itself to the heads of firms, so greatly would it interfere with business of all kinds in that world's centre.

It is interesting to study the early recorde of the observance of Christmas Day. In a pre- . vious Christmas article we showed that its

origin was distinctly pagan and quite unconnected with the birth of Jesus Christ. Indeed, many early writers holds that it was a special providence that appointed the birth of Christ to take place in the midst of pagan festivals. Menander gives a long account of these, and considers that a festival held on the shortest day-the winter solstice presented the opportunity of a transition to the Christian point of view ; Christ, the sun of the spiritual world, being compared with the sun of the material world. The comparison was carried still further, for as in the material world it is after dark. ness has reached its highest point that the end of its dominion is already near, and the light begins to acquire fresh power, so, too, in the spiritual world Christ, the spiritual sun, must appear to make an end of the kingdom of darkness. But the date to be observed presented a difficulty, and while the Western Churches decided on the 25th December, the Eastern Churches deferred it till the Epiphany. Hence the difference of dates at the present time.

Christmas is a time when absent friends claim a goodly share of our thoughts. Coupled with these, no doubt, in the minds of many Englishmen resident in Egypt, is the regret that they cannot be in the old country "to put their legs under the parental mahogany," and enjoy the roast beef of Old England, or the plump Norfolk turkey. These are things that are perhaps not obtainable in this country But we would say to our young friends, "Cheer up! Cold storage has been introduced and if you cannot feast on a good sirloin of Scotch -beef, you may get that excellent substitute, a joint of the rich meat that comes from all parts, Vorth, Central, and South, of the American continent and which loses so little of its flavour in the freezing process, that it is often enjoy. ed as much as, and even preferred before, - when the source from which it comes is not known, the home fed beef And the children (blessthem !), what of them at Christmas tine! A glance at the shop windows fully assures us that they are not forgotten. It is worth while to pay a visit to the bazaars and large drapery establishments if only to note the plethora of dolls, mechanical toys, and novelties of all descriptions that are offered to the purchaser vf presents for the little ones. The Christmas tree, too, is quite an institution in Egypt. So we wish to "one and all, both great and small," ävery Merry Christmas and a Happy New

Year. Now-a-days it is the custom to alter the wish to that for a Happy Christmas, and tak. ing into consideration the very many cases where the season from various causes cannot be a merry one, the old wish often seems a mockery. We can wish everybody happiness from the bottom of our hearts.

The "good cheer" of Christmas is too well established a thing for the old customs ever to be broken. The fashions may change and the Yule Log disappear, but never will Christ mastide cease to be associated with family reunions and general feasting. Of late years a growing tendency has manifested itself to make the festival & time for a more general loosening of the purse-strings than formerly. That Christmas-time is the only period of the year that many open their hearts and their purses for the benefit of the poor is a sail reflection, and reminds us of so many people who only put on religion with their Sunday

lothes and feel when they take them off that there is no necessity to think about spiritual natters for another six days. None the less lo we rejoice to see the movement extend rear after year, and if the progress is slow we rust that it will be sure. In the large cities of Cairo and Alexandria we have many destiute wanderers, who will be glad to receive ome of the good things of the season, and lo doubt the Rudolpb and other Homes will eceive an increase of support that will enable hem to give the poor who apply to them a ood Christmas meal

div.head: Tho Plague.
div.p: Daring the week ending the 23rd inst. there were 24 cases of plagne reported for all Egypt, 4 in Alexandris, 17 in the Nag Hamadi district, and 8 in the Tala distriot. The total of cares from January 1 to the 23rd inst. was 625, against 266 in the corresponding period 1906 and 841 for 1904. There were 18 death ond 3 recoveries last week and 11 patients romain ander treatment. There are no fresh cases to-day.

div.head: A Much-Married Man.
div.p: A curions story comes from Samalout of a very much-married man. Recently his children asked the Maglis el Hasby at that town to dominate a guardian to look after their father, who, they declared, was wasting bis sabstance in selling fifty one feddans of excellent agrioultural land belonging to bim and marrying a fresh wife for every teddan he disposed of. He thus managed to esponse fifty-one wives. The Moglis el Hasby sadotioned the application of tbe children and ordered a goardiao to be appointed, but their uxorious father bas appealed.

div.head: Thought Transmlesion.
div.p: The sén doe given on Sunday night at the Khedivial Hotel by M. Door Leblado and his mediom before a small but very select audience was a most interesting demonstra tion of conjuring tricks and thought-reading. The performance was divided into tbree parts. The first consisted in a series of clever conjaring feate, followed by an exposition of the trioks employed to do them. The second part was devoted to tbongbt-reading, and here the modiom, blindfolded and in a trance, witboat any direct contact with the hypnoticor, carried out many clover and complicated aots at the request of some of the spectators. In the third part the medium, whilst in the trance, transported herself anywhere and gave vivid and exciting desoriptions o' what distant relatives or friends were doing at that mo mont in Rossia, America, the Sadan, etc. The evening broke op with some clever thooght reading by the "magio band" table, whicb by repeated taps on the glass on which it was laid answered all sorts of questions. At the end of the performance it was annoupoed that person wishing to consult privately tbe mediom with regard to distant relatives or on other points could do so in the morning at the Khedivial Hotel.

div.head:
WALKER AND MEIMARACHI.
LOCAL AND LONDON BOARDS.
div.p: An important meeting of the shareholders of Walker and Meimaracbi Limited was beld on Saturday afternoon at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, and 80,000 shares were represented. The chair was taken by Maitre Carton de Wiart, chairman of the looal board, and the otber members of that board present were George Nongovich Bey, Mr. Constantine Meimarachi and Mr. Landaner.

Moltre Carton de Wiart said that that assembly was not a general meeting, that it was an act, pot provided for in the statates, but that it was nevertheless a Deoessary aot, although, be added, "there are no pessimistio considerations to preoconpy 08, as the company's affaire are most satisfactory. A coording to the statutes the company is Englisb, under British law, and managed in London. Therefore all meetings must be held in London. The chairman went on to say that the company last year was in need of foods. The emission was almost entirely covered in Egypt by the members of the board and their friende. Since then the administration had set to work ; tbey bad done their best, for already thore was £35,000 worth of business more than at the same period last year; besides they had arquired a valuable property ; tbey bought & plot for £75,000, of which oply balt was atilized for building the shops on, the other half baviog been sold for £56,000, thus reducing the price of the remaioing plot to £18,000. "How is it, however, that tbe sbares are below pall' be said. The reason is that the two board, the one in London and the one in Cairo, differed in opinion in regard to this enterprise. It was not suffi sient to wish that the board were transferred to Cairo, but it would be necessary to change the statates. Tbe sharebolders have a right to eff sot this change ; they can ask at the general meeting to bave the board transerred to Cairo. Bat for the present this is but a vain wish.

"As far I am concerned," continued Maitre Carton de Wiart, "I hall most decidedly not submit to a board in London." An ordinary geDeral meeting will be held in London in order to examine the accounts, and an extraordinary general meeting to decide whether the abovestated modification will be made or not: it I would be necessary that all shareholders be
represented at this meeting. The chairman, in or noludiog, made very reasoring statements in regard to the company's business.

M. Paul Oziol declared that the board abould certainly be in Cairo, and blamed the board in London for having delayed six months before commenoing the works; be asked whether it would not be possible to prosecute |tbe English board for their mismanagement of affairs.
M. Conika expressed the same views on the subject.

Maitre Carton de Wiart pointed out that of | 293,000 shares only 80,000 were represented. It was evident that the greater part of the capital was in England, but there were more tban 80,000 sbares in Egypt.
Energetio measures must be taken and a delegate sent to London.
The meeting unapimoasly expressed them selves desirous to see the board transferrod to | Cairo

div.head: KHEDIVE'S RAILWAY.
div.p: The Khedive's railway, it is expected, will be 230 kilometres in length by next Jane, wbrn it will be forty kilon etres from Marsa Matrouh. The line now consists of 93 kilometres of normal and 70 kilometres of narrow gange. The line has not been damaged extensively by the recent floode, as bad teen reported.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY
div.p: On the retirement of Bi Lewa Ahmed Pasha Z ki, the Sirdar, in a farewell order, "desires to record his spreciation of the excellent services performed by this officer during a long and distinguisbed career in His Highness's Army. The Sirdar desires on bebalf of the Army to offer E Lewa Abmed Pasha Zəki every good wish for the fature."
El Kaimakam Ibrahim Bay Sabri, Deputy Assistant Adjatant General, has been promoted to the rank of Miralai, and El Kaimakam E. C. Midwinter Bay, D S.O., Badan Government to that of Temporary Miralai.
BI Bimbashi E0.A. Nowoombe has been granted the temporary rank of Kaimakam, whilst bolding the appointment of Traffic Manager, Sudan Government Railways.
Leave of absence has been granted to El Kaimakam Carter Bay, commanding 9:b Sudanese, to Marob 13.

Lieutenant G. B. Hobart, the York and Lancaster Regiment, bas reported bis arrival in Egypt from England, and been taken on the strength of the Bgyptian Army, with the rank of Bimbasbi. He has been posted to the 16tb Battalion.

An Army Order statos that it is strictly torbidden to lend fire arms to natives for any purpose whatsoever. Should fire-arms belonging to anyone in or attacbed to the Army be found in possession of patives they will be confiscated.

Another Order announoes that the use of "Service Stamps" will be discontinued from tbe 1st February, 1907. Departments and units stationed in Egypt will furnish a statement direct to the Assistant Adjutant General, Wan Office, C iro, by the 7th Jangary Dext, sbowing the namber of stamp'8, by values, reqoired by them during the period from 1st February to 3'st December, 1907. The rates of postage on letters, parcels, etc., will be the game as for tbe poblio. Stamps of tbe value of 1, 2, 3, 5, ald 20 milliemer, surcharged O.H.H 8.," will be issued and are only to bo used for Govern ment corresponder.co, eto.

div.head:
FATAL EXPLOSION.
TWO MEN KILLED AT SUEZ.
div.p: ( From UUR CORRESPONDENT. )

Saez, Satorday. Yesterday evening a very ead accident bappened at the Attaka quarries at Saez. While a pomber of miners, attor having set fire to a mine, were with drawing, apparently owing to insufficient fase, the charge suddenly exploded, killing two men on tbe spot and seriously wounding four. All were of Hellonio Dationality. The corpses of the opfortunate victims,who leave large families, were conveyed to the Greek cemetery this morning, where they were bariel after the usual formalities.

'XMAS PESTIVITIES. The members of the Cercle International da Canal de Suez at Port Tewfik will have a Christmas Tree at the club on Christmas day, in order to entertain the members' children, after which a obildren's ball will be given. At 9 p.m. a small dance will be beld.

TAB PILGRIMAGE. A considerable bomber of Egyptian pilgrims are now at Suez en route to Mooon. The town is very crowded, especially the Passport Offices, which are practically surrounded from day. break to midnight.

div.head: IMPORTANT LAND SALE.
div.p: An important sale of landed property at Ghezireb bas just been concluded by Messrs. G. Bialobos & Co., stockbrokers of Cairo, wbo bave porobased from the Egyptian Hotels Company (Baehler) on behalf of a powerful local syndicate a plot consisting of 10,000 square metres at L. B. 130,000, being at the rate of L E. 13 the metre, which constitutea record price for land in that sabarb. The property is situated in close proximity to Ghezireh Palace Hotel and will faca the new bridge that is to be erected across the Nile at Boulac. It consists of the old building known as the Harem, which bas been used lately as an annexe to the hotel. The syndicate intend demolishing this building and erecting on the plot's number of bigb-ola 8 residences and shops.

The high price obtained for this land partly accounts, we are informed, for the sadden rise that has taken place in the last few days in the shares of the Egyptian Hotels Company, which are expected to go still higher in the Dear future when the company dispose of the remainder of their land at Gbezireb.

div.head: SAILORS AND SOLDIBRS' INSTITUTE
div.p: The fancy sale at the above institute on the 19th inst. passed off most successtally and pleasantly. A day of sansbide, exquisite masio, the spacious hall, and the delicious tes provid ed in the refreshment room, all combined to make the afternoon most enjoyable.

At an early bour the children's stall was be. sieged by the happy possessors of yellow tickets, and a great deal of business was done in a very short time. This stall was most ably presided over by Mrs. Morrison and the Misses Davis, assisted by Miss Claxton, Rov. Grabam (H.M.S. Venus), and Mr. E. Henley (E/T.C.), and bad been organised and arranged by the ladies beforeband, so that notwithstanding the rash of little people, there was no confa. sion or disorder. A bookstall, beld by the Misses Atkin, was very profitable. The articles on this stall, though dainty and useful, were inexpensive, and there must bave been many parcbarers to enable these ladies to band in the sum of over £6 (including sale of tickets).

Mrs. Kingbam's flower stall was most artistically arranged, and transformed that portion of the ball into a garden of beauty. The exquisite "battonholes" (provided at Mrs. Kingbam's expense) sold off rapidly. This lady and her daughter are much to be congratulated upon the great 8000888 aobioved b their combined efforts, over £18 being taken during the afternoon.

A large stall, presided over by Mrs. Roos, Mrs. Gordon, and Miss Lang Anderson, with splendid assistanoe from other ladies, was mosy profitable. The articles were quiokly cleared off, and the sum of £27.11.0 (including sale of tickets) was realized. At this stall Master Bssil Rees proved himself to be a most snocessful salesman.

Great praise is due to Miss Christabel Carver and the ladies who do efficiently presided over the refreshments. Notbing could exceed the kind attention shown by these ladies to all, and that the daties ware ardaous is ovident, for within the space of one and a half hours, two bandred people were served with an excellent tea. Mrs. Sidney Carver kindly undertook the expenses (hiring orockery, eto.) connected with this stall, and contributed, amongst other things, the delicious home made bread and butter.

The following are those to whom thanks are doe for contributions to the refreshment and flower stalls, and for valued belp in selling tickets, dressing dolls, and making fanoy articles : Judge Sandars, Mrs. J. A. Willisme, Mr. Cbataway, Mrs. Pioton, Mr. Kindenico, Mme. Debbane, Mme. B. Zervadachi, Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. Rodocanachi, Mrs. Kingham, Mrs. Morrison, Mrs. Borohgrevinck, Mrs. Moge, Mrs. Peake, Misses Davis (valuable articles for stalls), Mrs. Sidney Carver, Mrs. P. Carver, Mrs. Percival, Mrs. John Atkin, Mrs. Hopkinson, Mrs. Chataway, Mi:838 Atkin, Mrs. Bowen, Miss Swan, and Mrs. Savidge. The total amount realiz:d during the day was P.T. 5,2531

div.head:
UP RIVER.
THE SEASON AT LUXOR.
div.p: ( FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT. )

Laxor, December 19. Visitors to Egypt are at length realizing that tbe trip op-river is far bet er ondertaken as soon as tbe cold weather first makes its appearance in Cairo. Not only do they thos get back to the genial warmth and sunshine, but they also are then able to return to the Capital when tbe bigh season is in full swing. if indeed the attractions of society are greater than those of antiquarian research surrounded by ideal conditions. i Already a great many visitors are in the neighbourhood; some engaged in business which is everywhere inoreasing, but mostly bent on pleasure and spending a pionio existence among the endless objects of interest botb in Luxor and close roand. Dababeabs, both large and small, are constantly arriving and leaving : for doubtless where time is unlimited this way of seeing the country has medyadvantages, and the restful life aboard in machto be desired. Coles Pasbo, Mrs. Coles, and their two daaghters have been ashore several times these last few daye, and Birch Pasba's steam laudoh has been at anchor to day while he and his bride have been exploring somewhat. Sir W. Ewart and his family are staying at the Luxor Hotel for the time being, and Col. and Mrs. Armstrong, Mr. and Mrs. Tite, the Rev. Sams and the Rev. Mr. Fetberstone are also staying at the same popular hotel, where the garden is one of its obiet attractions, with its tennis and croquet courts, its shady palms and trees, and its wealth of roses, mimosa, and other sweetly. smelling flowers. | The Countess Hedda de Brockdorff was also a visitor at the Laxor for a faw daye. She has now lett by the Mayflower for Assouan, where she will spend most of the winter on account of her bealth. She passes nearly overy winter abroad and knows a good part of India and the East, but this is her first stay in Egypt.

M. Naville is expected to arrive before long. His presence is anxiously awaited for at Deir el Babari as farther discoveries at that famous site are sur le tapis, and nothing can be done without him. Many artists are en camping in that neigbbourhood, the weather being fine enough to allow them to sleep in the open every night it fanoy takes them that way.

There are many advantages accraing from the position occupied by the Savoy Hotel, which lies at the fortber end of the village to that occupied by the Loxor Hotel and right on the river bank. It is an imposing and comfortable-looking building approached by an avende of palms and mimosa ; and owns a wide and shady verandab well fornished with easy chairs, and the largest bull loange at present in Luxor. Tea is often served, too, in the two kiosks at the river gate from whence steps lead to the sailing boats which ply op and down and across the river. This hotel has many old-established patrons, and many of the artists at Deirel Babari and ober places in the neighbourhood make it their headquarters. Among these may be mentioned Mr. Henry Simprop, Mr. Walter Tyndale, Migs McCracken, Miss Haddon, and Miss Parmioter. The Rev. Dr. Colin Campbell and Mrs. Campbell are spending the entire season at the Savoy. Dr. Colin Campbell is one of the best-known of our prosent-day Egyptologists, and his refatation most ofttimos be irksome to bim : for people seek his authority at every tarn, and will not allow bim to pursue his investigations in private.
The Barop von Gruodan, from the Imperial German Consulate General, Cairo, is also staying at the Savoy Hotel.

div.head: MLLE. BRANDES IN CAIRO.
"RAFALE."
div.p: The farewell piece was Bernstein's "Rafale," which is the drama of a gambler. Chagoeroy the lover of Hélène de Bréchebel, and representative of a racing stable finadoed by men whose names do not appear, loses at baccarat some £26,000 which be should band over to these people as the results of a sale of racehorses. All efforts to raise the sum in time fail, and be ends the problem by suicide. Of course the ipoidental 1880ee, Hélène's love and persistence which forces his confession, ber struggle with her rich tatber seeking advancement among the pobility, but yet only too business-like-for be forces ber confegeion in ber torn-bis interview with the contemptuous, younger son,- all these aro and make the play,-a very great play too. Apd it is the drama of those two. Both Mlle Brandès and M. Rousselle were at their height ; her frantio efforts with any and every One who might save her lover, the great scene with ber fatber, these showed how Martbe Brando's can move and bold as. And be also held 08-bis confession wherein be makes light of all at the end, taking pleasure oven in losing, his soene with ber father, cynical, Opapproachable, incomprehensible to the poor, sbrowd parvenu – and, greatest of all that M. Rousselle has done in these siz nights, his silence, resolved, lingering ratber than besitat ing over bis farewell to all things--all little tiny familiar details of the room that witnessed love, elation, loer, and at last decision as of one content with himself--these scenes were beyond praise. For both of them, we could not ask for words, we would bat wait and watch their eyer, their lips about to open perbaps, then close : no word might be spokon, but the silence said all. The scene lived in itself before us, in its own light, created by these two.

The rest were surprisingly good. M. Gournao and Mme. Laure, the two Lebourgs, wero faaltloss, M. Alerme was, as ever, dry, cypical, almost malicious, entirely 80 when Hélène know and repulsed that only evil condition on which be might and would help ber, rancorous in his so-called socialism – but ever quiet, driving every point home by the least mark in tone or glance. Those others wbo bad far less to do, did well, well enough to be notice, though these five "principals" overshadowed all else. The play from first to last was shown in its fall perfection. And so we have seen the last – for the time being — of Mlle Brandès apd M. Rousselle. I do not hesitate to mention the two together. Thoagb be bas pot, as I said before, the personality whiob remains through every part he plays, tbough be is the personage each time, and not one in many young and phases, yet his achievements are, I think, po less than bers or those of anyone in relation to the dramas be interprets.

We have had six wonderful nights, and seen six wonderful plays : and, I hear, we may, during next year, hope for more good thirga. Forandy comes in April. Guitry and Antoine may come. Look to it, playgoers of Cairo, that these and the great plays they will interpret meet the welcome they merit. I am only too glad to say, that though the house was not always filled, the audience showed kooner and keeper appreciation, night by night ; last night every one seemed to hang on every word and every glance of the actors : all the Doises, so often a curse to listeners, were sterr. ly and sharply repressed, and the few offenders, less ripping than sinned against by dranghts, cbairs to be moved and other worries, respond ed by subsiding at opoe, and rivalling their jadges in keen attention. May it always be go! And why not, when the life itself, perhaps of those we know, it may even come to pass, of ourselves, is shown so vivid and keen before our eyes, by those who can reveal and beigb ten its last least pbases and details ?

div.head:
OPERA AT ALEXANDRIA.
THE SEASON OPENS.
div.p: The opera season opened on Saturday night with "LA Bobème," the well known and ever. popular work of Paccipi. The theatre was packed and presented a most brilliant appear. ance. The interpretation on the whole may be termed good. "Rodolfo" the tenor (Signor Acerbi) is endowed with a fine and very pleasing voice particularly suited to the music he had to sing. His singing called for two "epoores." "Mimi" (Signor Belendi Livia) is not a new comer on the Zizipia stage ; ber magnificent interpretation of Carmen some years back is still fresh in the memory of the Zizinis "abon és." Her rendering of the role of "Mimi" was met with much applause. She combines good singing with excellent acting. She was particularly good in the death soone of the last act. Sigpora Prizi did well in the ongrateful role of "Musetta." The baryton (Dalbope) and the base Baldasseri were also good, the latter was encored in his solo. The orobestra under, tbe able direction of the Maestro Zoocani, now quite an old friend, - as it is the third year that he has directed the orobestra - could not have been better. It is premature to judge the merits of the troppe on a first performance, or ventore on an opinion as to tbe kind of season we are likely to have. Any such oriticism must be left for a later date.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Dachess of Marlborough, who is at resent at Sunderland House, Mayfair, is xpected to arrive in E:ypt early in the New Fear. The Dicbogs it strikingly beautiful woman, with dark hair, sympathetio eyes, a oooliar wistful expressiou, and an exqoisitely

odelled neck. When th Duchess made her Løbnt as Migg Conanelo Vanderbilt she w 19 dmired by all, and her rare type of beauty, racetal, girlish figare and wonderfully soft lear skin must bave aroused great envy in the hearts of bør fellow debutantes. Nor is sbe 388 beautiful to-day.

The Duchess is the only daughter of an American multi-millionaire, Mr. William K isam Vanderbilt, and, following the American yetem, she was carefully trained and edacated sa girl, receiving a most liberal adocation hiefly in Paris. Daring ber sobool years sbe also ravelled a great deal, and there is probably 0 part of Barope with which she is not well cquainted, while no better means could be round of brosdeping the mind and sympatbies. Bbe is a god daughter of Consuelo Duch 989 of Manchester, from whom she takes her Christian name, and it was at ber godmother's boose that be first met the Duke of Marlborough.

Count Arachot, Councillor of the Belgian Legation at Constantinople, whose engagement to Mlle Boghos Nabar Pasha we lately an mounoed, has arrived at Constantinople, where be will stay for some days, afterwards probeeding to Cannes for the marriage, which will take place sbortly.

To day Judge Charles Royle celebrates his sixty sixth birthday anniversary and we take this opportanity of tendering him our best wishes for many happy retorns of the day. Toe Judge, who is the foartb son of the late William Royle, a London solicitor, was born at Lymington, Hants, and from 1854 to 1863 he served as an officer in the Royal Navy. In 1865 he was called to the Bar at Lincoln's Inn and be is Jadge of the Egyptian Court of Appeal. His literary abilities are wall-known to Anglo-Bgyptians, and he is the author of "The Egyptian Campaigns."

The King has been pleased to give and grant onto Konneth Mackenzie Soott, Esq.. M.B., M.Ch., his Majesty's Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insigpia of the Poorth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieb, conferred apon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, sothorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Tarkey, in recognition of his services.

We regret to annoance the death of Mr. William J. Torkey, Professor of Gymnastics at Victoria College, Alexandria, who died at the Greek Hospital late on Saturday night after a short illness. He was only twentyfour years of age and his ontimely death bas created much sorrow among his many friends at the college, where he was very popolar.

div.head:
SITUATION IN MOROCCO.
AN ARMY IN RAGS
CHEREFIAN TROOPS OUTSIDE TANGIER

div.p: M. Pichon has announced to the Council of Ministers an improvement in the situation on the Algero Moroocan frontier.

Guebbaa Army ia now enoamped outside the city. His men are mostly in rage. The local Governor borrowed the liveries of servants of European residents to give a respectable appearance to his few troops when he went out to meet Guebbas.
There is a strong feeling amongst Europeans thatt Guebbaa' troops would be more likely to attack Europeans than El Raiaoli'a men.
Later.
The Governor of the city went ont to meet Guebba's troops. El Raisilis followers are holding aloof.

Telegrams from Spanish sources state the Mooriah Pretender was victorious in the re ent fighting against the Kabyled, and is seeking the support of the Riffs for an attack on the Imperial army. (Reuter)
It is reported from Tangier that the War Minister Guebbas has arrived there at the head of the Chereefian troops. (Harvas)

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: REPORT OF THE DIRECTORS

Tne directors consider the results attained in the year ended September 30 as evidenoirg the high intrinsic and economic value of the rights possessed by the corporation. '1 he operations reviewed have not been of an ex peditionary nature Tbe definite ascertain­ment of the permanency and excellency of tbe water supply dispelled any doubts that may have existed respecting it, and clearly revealed the land as the constitutive factor in deter mining the prosperity of the enterprise. Land development has consequently received primary consideration. The subsidiary works are im cortant, and in tbe opinion ot the directors are capable of contributing in no small degree to tbe corporation's earning capacity, but relatively to the land they are quite subei diary. A preliminary number of bores have been pat down, and land for experimental purposes, on which cotton and numerous other crops have been most successfully grown, has been cultivated around each of the finished wells. Pending the completion of the 'ail way, which at the oLwe of tbe year under review wm completely laid to kilometre 67, the number of drilling machines has been strictly limited owing to tbe excessive cost of camel transport Mineral research has been actively prosecuted, and a large amount of analytical and exploratory work hu been carried out, while actual divelopment of proved beds of earthy minerals has bien accomplished. The directors record that tbe Egyptian Government have missed no opp^r tunity of extending their assistance to tbe cor poration in matters pertaining to the develop ment of the ones ; and they are confi lent th it tbe attitude of the G jvernmeut will continue to be of the most friendly character. Recent expren non has been given to the deteriuinati n of tbe Government to assist the corporation in its operations in every reasonable way. In order to complete the railway to Khugih as early as possible in the coming year and to oops w th the work of land reclamation on a large scale, arrangements are being male for the early issue of the balance of capital. Meantime the final call of 5s. per share, making all shares fully paid, has been made, so as to enable vigorous construction to proceed an interruptedly. div.head:
DEAN BUTCHER'S RETIREMENT.
HIS OLD PARISHIONERS
div.p: The following communication has been re chived by Lord Cromer —
To His Excellency Lord Cromer, PC., G.C.M.G., &o., Ac, &c.

My Lord,—I read with extreme pleasure in tbe "PallMallGdizette"of the7th insU.that your Lordship presided at a meeting of the English and American residents in Cairo, to consider the question of presenting a testimonial to tbe Very Rev. Dean Butcher. It has occurred to me that it would, perhaps, be interesting to your Lordship and those with wh^m yon are acting, to know the opinion of the parishioners of Hammersmith on tbe departure of Mr Butcher 42 years ago after having served as Curate of the Parish Church for fi e years.

Tbe enclosed statement will appear in the Paul's Pariah Magazine for January next, and if your L?rd-hip shoo'd consider it would be of interest at the present juncture you are at liberty to communicate any portion of it t) the English press in Cairo.

As a lad of 12 years old I hive a distinct recollection of the kindly feeling entertained by all classes for Mr. Butcher, and the univer sal regret at his departure , I also remember with gratitude his kindness to my sick mother who died the year after he left.

I trust your Lordship will pardon me tor venturing to address yin, but 1 could not resist giving yon this i iformation regarding one for whom 1 have always entertained th^ highest feelings of respect and affection. — I have, etc ,
8. Martin.
Hammersmith, December 13th.
The following is the atatemeut referred to : —
DE\N BUTCHER.

Iu June, 1861, the Rev. Charles Henry Batcher, M.A., resigned tbe curacy of St Paul'n, H immersurith, to take uphi< datiei as Consular Chaplain at Shanghai. During ths fivey aro be had worked in Hammersmith he had endeared himself to the parishioners
Happily there are a few of tbe present congregation, of whom tba writer is one, who remember his sterling worth as a minister and preacher, and who still regard him with affectionate remembrance.

It was confi iently anticipated that Mr. Bu' ober would make his mark in th] Church, and his services were so highly appreciated that in 1876 he was raised to the dignity of Dean of tbe Ca'b>dral of the 11 >'y T iiity, Slnugha .

Iu 1883 he reiigne i the Deane y, and was appointed Chaplain of All Saint", Cairo, Mr Bucher also held tbe o Hi e of E. C. Arcbdeao >n ia Egypt from 1890 to 1895. Advancing years have now compelled his retirement.

[Here follows a report of the recent meeting at tbe British Agency where it was announ­ced that the testimonial would take the form of a purse of gold. The Parish Magazine's article then procaeds as follows ]
It may be of interest to recall a similar pre­sentation as the one proposed which was male by the congregationofS . Pa il's, Hammersmith, 42 years ago.

The testimonial consisted of an illuminate! address, a silver salver, an I a purse of £100. It
was presented m the occasion of a schorl treat held in ths grounds of an o'd house in Shepherd's Bush Road, known as' Tbe Poplars," the site of wh'ch is now marked by Poplar Grove. The chair was taken by tbe Rev. J. Connell, Vicar, who was supported by Mr W. Smith, Churchwarden (founder of Smith's Almshouses), Dr. Moxey, Mt Wing, Mr. Jamei Hunt, Mr A. J. Riberts (late Vestry Clerk), Rev. W. L. Collett, late Vicar of St. Stephen's, and other leading parishioners.
Tbe Vioar read the following address. Hammersmith, St. Paul's Vestry,
Jane, 1864
To the Rev. Charles Henry Butcher, M. A. Rev and Very Dear Sir,

In response to the very general desire of tbs Congregation of St. Paul's a Teskimoaial Subscription List was opened shortly after the abnonnoemeat of year anticipated removal. It was felt instinctively that your earnest pastoral labour-', diligent ca-e, and unwearied anxiety for the spiritual welfare of our deutely populat­ed pariah during five years' residence amongtt us should not pass away without special re­cognition and record. These sentiments, atreog- thenel in many by feeling] of da'p personal regard and aff lotion have found their natural expression (at th's juncture) in the eager anxiety of all classci without exception to participate in a parting evidence of goodwill and Christian sympathy. It has been judged best to leave our united freewill offering (to which the poorest have heartily contributed acoordiag to theiv ability) entirely at your dis- pAsal rather than convey it in a form (however . gratifying) which might prove cumbersome it not useless in your far-c ff home and untried position. Be assured wa express alike our own and the spontaneous universal feeling of all with whom you have been associated here when in taking leave we wish you and ye ars health and happiness, but above all that in your future sphere of duty you may expariencj personally and be made to others a rich sourej of abundant blessing approved unto God, a workman that needeth not be ashamed, rightly dividing 'The Word of Truth."
We have pleasure in signing ourselves on behalf of subscribers and friends,
Reverend and Dear Sir, Years most sincerely,
Jame.^ Connfll, Vicar of Him men; mi th. William Smith Churchwarden. Edwajld Bird, John C. Swail, Joseph Crookes, Char les Andrews.

The sslver bore the following inscrip'ion : — 'Tiv<» ntvl to the Rev. C. H. Buuchar, M.A., with a I'tir-M <>f Gold, by the Congregation of St. Paul A HniHiihTHnr.th, and other Friends in appreciation of In- earnest Christian Ministry, and aa token of their deep |>er*ooal regard.
June, 1864

The Rev. Mr. Butcher, whose occasionally faltering voice betrayed tbe emotion be felt, replied in very grateful terms, concluding by expressing his pain at parting with his friends at Hammersmith of whom he should alwayi think with tbe deepest regard

The fjw remaining friends with whom be parted 42 years ago wish him many years of peaceful happiness after his long and arduous service for the Master, and should opportunity offer would expend him a hearty welcome to the scene of bi; first curacy, somewhat altered since be left it, and we are sure this feeling will be sbared by every member of the con­gregation of the new St. Paul's Church.
S. Martin

div.head: THE PORT SAID AFFAIR
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egtptian Gazette

Sir,—I am sure that a a amber of your readers will agree with me that the police officer who had the misfjrtuoe of colliding with two pas •ODgeM in the Rae de Uoaameroe, Port Said, on Thursday last deserves great sympathy, and may we hope that the Gjvwrnment will eet be backward in acknowledging the gellant servicer of their worthy officer ami of the manner in which he performed his duty. Tbe promptitude of the whole businem is amasiag and worthy of note. Tbe steamre arrived at about 10 aea. and within two short hours one of the two gentlemen had not only comssitled tbe oSeeos but had beta triad before His Msjeety'a British Consul for drunkenness and aresok, and before 12 o'olook was ia the aative prison sarviag bio term ofotven days. One cannot help wonder ing how iaso short a time, withe prisoner, as, I anderetead under the iotlmoe of druk, the authorities ware able to satisfy themselves that they were dealing with a British subject. Bosh satisinotion it aaraui thiy did have, inMmunh aa the prisoner was dealt with by the Britirii Consul Gsureal.

However, Mr. Editor, without occupying more opsboe, may I suggrei khat it weold be no opportune moment to open a eebeeriptieo lirt for the porpoee of pereewtiap the eonsfobte with a memento of the event and aa it terms ho oams off wikb adsmsged tasbooebe, I haodly think we could do bettor than let snob a prenentetiMK in tbe nhsenos of a Viotoria Crou, take the formof a new pines of hesdgosr. K others of the Britmh commnnity will give their snpport I should he delighted to open the tot with a donation ot ten millisnaee. Thanking you for the space,—Yours, etc ,
A Bbitishir.

div.head: PIGEON SHOOTING AT HBLOUAN.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Barnau Gaikttb."

Dear Sir,—1 am an occasional visitor to Helouan, and last Sunday I was sargsised to find that pigeon shootmg was being oasriod on daring the afternoon, very oloau to ous of the principal hotels, so alone, in feet, that one lady visitor informed me that a few days before, after n pigeon shooting match, five wounded birds had fluttered into het room through the open window. 1 will not experea my views as to the cruelty of this so sailed "sport " of pigeon shooting. Most English people, I believe, have decided opinions on the sob jeot. I would merely suggest that if the hotdh in Helouan wish to lose their Britiab patienag", there is no easier way for them to tong this about than by allowing thio form- of sport to be carried on at little more than 100 yards distance from their visitors' bed rooms—I sm, etc.,
